content: A Retrospective of House Rules Changes Since the 110th Congress examines rules changes adopted by the House at the beginning of a new Congress. The majority party organizes the House, elects the Speaker, chairs committees, and manages the legislative agenda. Each new House adopts changes to the rules, a feature unique to the House. The first report in the series covered rules changes from the 104th to the 109th Congress. The report examines rules changes made by the House since the 110th Congress, focusing on the Democratic majority in the 110th and 111th Congresses and the Republican majority in the 112th to 115th Congresses. The changes are grouped into five broad areas and further subdivided by subject or Congress. The report analyzes rules changes in the House from the 110th to the 115th Congresses, focusing on Democratic and Republican majorities. It covers critiques, proposed amendments, and changes in committees, chamber, budget, administration, and ethics standards.
